description.narrative:
By 2030, millions of older people will enjoy a better quality of life, through improved wellbeing, enhanced dignity and greater voice. In order to achieve this, HelpAge International will prioritize 10 focus areas: 1. Inspire a movement for change- Supporting older people and civil society to unite and demand change, mobilising a peoples movement for a fairer world for everyone to grow old in, promoting older peoples rights and transforming the way people think, feel and act on ageing. 2. Create a society for all ages- Promoting inclusive environments and communities integrating all ages, where older people feel connected and can participate equally as they wish. 3. Improve income security-Protecting older peoples independence and Sense of purpose by promoting social pensions, access to decent work, economic opportunities and financial services without discrimination. 4. Promote age-inclusive systems- Calling for and securing ratification of age inclusive laws, policies and systems to guarantee older peoples rights across all sectors, tracking implementation and holding actors to account. 5. Support healthy ageing- Supporting the transformation of systems to promote healthy ageing, including the implementation of inclusive universal health coverage and long-term care and support systems. 6. Deliver inclusive humanitarian action-Promoting age-inclusive humanitarian preparedness and response to ensure older people are protected, feel safe and have full access to assistance. 7. Challenge violence, abuse and neglect- Exposing the risks of violence, abuse and neglect older people face, with a particular focus on older women, and work with others to take action. 8. Take a stand against ageism- Taking a stand against ageism, engaging all stakeholders including duty bearers, the wider community and older people themselves. It will promote positive attitudes and behavior towards older people, ensuring their contribution is valued and they are treated fairly and with respect. 9. Embrace technology- Advocating for older people to receive maximum benefit and minimum harm from technological change in all sectors of society. 10. Foster lifelong learning- Promoting access to lifelong learning, professional and personal opportunities, as well as other educational opportunities so that older people develop their full potential to participate in society. Complementary to the Core Activities, this contribution supports HelpAge's Global COVID-19 Response Plan so that older people are protected by reducing their exposure to COVID-19 through age inclusive preparedness, response and recovery.
In March 2022 an agreement amendment was decided for support to older and disabled people in Ukraine and refugees in Moldova with NFI, health and mental health and psycho social support.

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Established in 1983, HelpAge International (HAI) is a civil society organisation that supports older people to claim their rights and challenge discrimination and poverty, so that they can lead dignified, secure, active and healthy lives. The organization represents a global network of civil society organisations working to promote and protect the rights of older women and men in nearly 90 countries, with over 157 member organisations, the majority of which are located in Low and Middle Income Countries (LMICs). HAI works with a wide range of activities, covering advocacy, development and humanitarian operations.
In the previous collaboration (2015-2019), core funding from Sida supported a 5 year strategy (2015-2020) with a focus on income, health and care, voice and inclusion (gender and disability). During this period, HAI has specifically strengthened their work with health systems strengthening (also in collaboration with WHO), Non Communicable Diseases (NCDs), including mental health, and mainstreaming gender equality and inclusion (focus on disability).
This contribution refers to core funding support from Sida to enable HAI to implement their new 10 year strategy (2020-2030). The 2030 strategy identifies 10 focus areas (including health and education) to achieve a positive impact on the quality of life of the poorest older people, with a focus on wellbeing, dignity and voice. Of the 10 focus areas, the 2020-22 planning priorities include: 1. Inspire a movement for change; 2. Promote age-inclusive systems; 3. Champion healthy ageing; 4. Deliver inclusive humanitarian action; 5. Challenge violence, abuse and neglect. Complementary to the Core Activities, additional support targets HAI's Global COVID-19 Response Plan.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 HelpAge International (HAI), som grundades 1983, är en civilsamhällsorganisation som stödjer äldre att hävda sina rättigheter och minska diskriminering och fattigdom bland äldre så att de kan leva värdiga, säkra, aktiva och hälsosamma liv. Organisationen representerar ett globalt nätverk av civilsamhällsorganisationer som arbetar för att främja och skydda äldre kvinnors och mäns rättigheter i nästan 90 länder, med över 157 medlemsorganisationer, varav huvuddelen ligger i låg- och medelinkomstländer (LMIC). HAI arbetar med ett brett spektrum av aktiviteter för påverkansarbete och långsiktig hållbar utveckling samt humanitära insatser.
Under det tidigare samarbetet (2015-2019) stödde Sidas kärnfinansiering en 5-årig strategi (2015-2020) med fokus på inkomst, hälsa och vård, röst och inkludering (kön och funktionshinder). Under den perioden stärkte HAI särskilt sitt arbete med hälsosystem (delvis i samarbete med WHO), icke-överförbara sjukdomar (NCD) inkluderande mental hälsa, och sitt arbete med att integrera jämställdhet och inkludering av kön (fokus på funktionshinder).
Detta bidrag avser kärnfinansieringsstöd från Sida för att HAI ska kunna påbörja implementeringen av sin nya 10-åriga strategi (2020-2030). 2030-strategin identifierar 10 fokusområden (inklusive hälsa och utbildning) för att uppnå en positiv inverkan på livskvaliteten för de fattigaste äldre med fokus på välbefinnande, värdighet och röst. Av de tio fokusområdena inkluderar prioriteringarna för planeringen 2020-22; 1. Inspirera en rörelse för förändring; 2. Främja åldersinkluderande system. 3. Främja hälsosamt åldrande; 4. Leverera inkluderande humanitära insatser; 5. Motverka våld, övergrepp och försummelse. Som ett komplement till kärnverksamheten innefattar detta beslut även stöd från Sida att täcka HAI: s Globala COVID-19 Handlings Plan.

description.narrative:
HelpAges new Strategy 2030 seeks to support opportunities for older people and future generations to claim their rights. HelpAge focus on the quality of life for older people through improved well-being and creating a sustainable and equal society for all. Due to covid-19, HelpAge has had to adjust the pace of planned change. A new structure has been designed ensuring a sustainable model in line with the resources. The key anchors in this change are: Our Values (developed and launched in 2019), a commitment to a rights-based approach and to work as a convenor, supporter and thought leader with partners to achieve change at a local level.
HelpAge is now making three strategic shifts:
Localisation: HelpAge is building national capacity to create a more sustainable approach to change. Each of the 14 country offices review the local context, what civil society structure is in place, and how change can be achieved with which partners. Then a context specific transition plan will be developed in each country.
Partner-led programming: HelpAge will move away from direct implementation and own offices, to support local organisations. This process has during 3 years made the partner-led programme portfolio growing by 37%.
HelpAge has launched a new global operations structure in April 2021 to take forward their 4 priority areas: A Society for All Ages, Healthy Ageing, Secure Income and Inclusive Humanitarian Action. The current structure of regional and London offices will be replaced by new global technical teams that lead on programme support, advocacy and influencing, technical support and global HR, communications and operations teams to support them will be created. This transition will take place in three phases until March 2023.
HelpAge has during 2021 started the transformation with a shift away from regional offices and a head office structure, to a new global operating model. HelpAges global staff level in the new structure is 370 people.
Example of results during the reporting period:
Covid-19: • 154,440 older people (90,242 older women) affected by Covid-19 were supported through HelpAge and network members health and care projects and interventions in 10 countries • 9 million older people (5.4 million older women) in six countries received additional Covid-19 income support from their government • 432,530 people of all ages received Covid-19 humanitarian assistance from the HelpAge network • 42,344 older people received improved protection through psycho-social counselling and access to enhanced reporting systems which ensure safe and dignified humanitarian support.
From March until June 2020 HelpAge reached in its covid-19 response over 600,000 people directly through relief items, services and support and responded in 33 low and middle income countries. this was made through adapting programming; assessing older peoples needs; distribution of food and non-food items; include hygiene and dignity kits; strengthening health and care and emergency cash transfers and social protection.
Income security • 14 million older people in 11 countries received a social pension; just over 1 million older people received support for the first time • Just over £1 billion was paid to older people in 9 countries where HelpAge has actively worked on social pensions • 12,600 older people (63 percent women) across 13 countries had their financial and food security protected and supported through our humanitarian and disaster risk reduction programmes
HelpAge is working in partnership with WHO engaged with the ongoing Decade of Healthy Ageing. Also collaboration with NCD Alliance concerning NCDs and older people during covid-19 is ongoing.
The community-based programmes provided platforms for providing additional support to those most at risk when Covid struck. HelpAge provide direct cash and in-kind support, disseminate information to older people, and undertake targeted advocacy to include older people in emergency social protection measures.
Healthy ageing • 447,000 older people in 14 countries received better health and care services or support through HelpAges work, the majority of whom were older women (60 percent) • 1.6 million older people benefited from new or improved government health and care policies • 57,300 older people (56 percent women) in 10 countries had their health, care, and nutrition requirements provided for and protected through HelpAges humanitarian crisis response
Inclusive humanitarian action • 597,600 older people 51 percent women received humanitarian aid in 20 countries through the work of HelpAge and its global network • 72,850 people across four countries took part in disaster preparedness work and training • 166,450 older people accessed support services related to violence, abuse, and neglect via HelpAge partners in Tanzania and Kyrgyzstan
HelpAge humanitarian response and DRR/adaptation work offer opportunities to learn from older peoples experiences, i e how older peoples knowledge can be used to contribute to local response plans.
Ageism and older peoples rights • HelpAge supported seven Age Demands Action (ADA - a global platform against ageism) campaigns to raise awareness and expose ageism and discrimination during the pandemic. Campaigns were led by network members in Argentina, Bosnia Herzegovina, Cameroon, the Philippines, Russia, Uganda, and Venezuela. • HelpAge launched a campaign to call for the inclusion of older people in Covid-19 government responses. • HelpAge developed a guide to exploring systemic ageism which will be used to support the future campaigning of our ADA partners.
Diversity, Equity and Inclusion HelpAge launched a Gender Equality Training Toolkit that enabled gender training to 229 staff, network members, and partners published an accessible easy-to-read publication, "Are the rules about Covid-19 in your country fair for older people? A guide to help you check".
HelpAge developed during 2021 a Voice Training Toolkit to help partners, network members, and staff understand the key elements of the framework and to strengthen their ability to implement activities that enable older people to be heard and responded to at all levels.
